article.headline: Silver logs highest finish since 2014, up more than 80% from 2020âs low
article.body: Silver rallied Tuesday to finish at its highest level since 2014, up by more than 80% from the yearâs low, benefiting as both a precious and industrial metal as it looks to catch up with goldâs impressive year-to-date performance. âSilver was long due for a catch-up with gold,â said Peter Grosskopf, chief executive officer at Sprott Inc. âAs a much smaller market, once investor interest enters in size, its supply side gets swamped.â As some parts of the global economy start to improve after COVID-19 shutdowns, silverâs âindustrial supply and demand side have balanced,â Grosskopf told MarketWatch. âThat creates a window for the wave of investment demand to push the price much higher.â In Tuesday trading, September silver contract US:SIU20 Â rose $1.37, or 6.8%, to settle at $21.557 an ounce on Comex. Prices based on the most-active contracts marked their highest settlement since March 2014, according to Dow Jones Market Data. They trade 83% above the year-to-date low of $11.772 seen on March 18, which was the lowest since January 2009. Silver prices had settled early last week, and again on Monday, at the highest since September 2016. Read:Why silver is trading at a nearly 4-year high Gains for silver compare with a climb in gold futures to their highest price in nearly nine years. On Tuesday, August gold US:GCQ20 Â rose $26.50, or 1.5%, to settle at $1,843.90 an ounce. Year to date, most-active gold futures trade about 21% higher, while silver is up by roughly 20%. Silver has seen the âbest of both worlds,â with its precious metal side boosted by safe-haven demand, as economies in China and the U.S. improve, proving the metal a lift as an industrial metal, said Jim Wyckoff, senior analyst at Kitco.com. Silver trades in the lower half of its historical trading range, and has âmuch more upside potential,â he told MarketWatch. Gold is not far from its all-time high, but silver still has long way to go before it nears its record high, making silver look âundervaluedâ to investors, he said. “ The all-time high for silver; in the coming years is not out of reach, and maybe much sooner than anybody thinks.â ” â Jim Wyckoff, Kitco.com The record settlement level for most-active gold futures stands at $1,891.90 from August 22, 2011. Silver futuresâ all-time settlement high was at $48.599 in April 2011, according to FactSet data. Ross Norman, chief executive officer of precious metals news and information provider Metals Daily, said now that silver has rallied, âthis frees gold up to continue what has already been an impressive rally,â and both metals are âbetter aligned.â âSilver has seen very strong inflows into both the [exchange-traded funds] and in the futures market on Comex, prompting a breakout on the charts,â he told MarketWatch. Given that, Metals Daily has adjusted its second-half 2020 forecast on the metal to $25, up from a previous forecast of $23. âGlobal macro events are positive precious metals and even though silver is partly an industrial metal, it is a case of a rising tide lifting all boats,â said Norman. As for how high silver prices may go from here, Grosskopf said silver has âmore torqueâ to move up than gold, and âintermediate chartsâ point to $30 an ounce. Wyckoff, meanwhile, would only say that the all-time high for silver âin the coming years is not out of reach, and maybe much sooner than anybody thinks.â
